title: 110_hr595
content: SHORT TITLE, FINDINGS, AND PURPOSE. The "Stimulating Leadership in Limiting Expenditures (or 'SLICE') Act of 2007" aims to address the projected federal budget deficits by rescinding lower-priority spending to reduce the need for increased borrowing. The "SLICE" Act of 2007 aims to reduce federal budget deficits by rescinding lower-priority spending, enabling the President to propose spending cuts for Congress to debate and vote on. The "SLICE" Act of 2007 introduces expedited consideration of proposed rescissions in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "SLICE" Act of 2007 allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriation Act within 3 days of enactment. The President must transmit a special message to Congress with a draft bill identifying the amount of budget authority to be rescinded. The "SLICE" Act of 2007 allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment. The President must send a special message to Congress with a draft bill specifying the amount of budget authority to be rescinded for each program, project, or activity. The special message must include details as outlined in section 1012(a). The House of Representatives must introduce a draft bill accompanying a special message within three legislative days. If not introduced, any Member of the House may introduce the bill. The bill will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations without substantive revision and must be reported within seven legislative days. The Committee on Appropriations must report a bill within seven legislative days, or it will be automatically discharged. A vote on final passage must be taken in the House of Representatives within the 10th legislative day. If passed, the bill will be transmitted to the Senate within one calendar day. Debate in the House of Representatives on a bill under this section shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. Motion to limit debate or reconsider the vote is not debatable. No recommitting or reconsidering the vote on the bill. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to bill procedures without debate. A bill sent to the Senate goes to the Committee on Appropriations for review and must be reported within seven legislative days. If not reported, the committee is discharged, and the bill is placed on the calendar for a vote within 10 days. The Senate must vote on a bill within 10 legislative days after it is transmitted. A motion to proceed to consider the bill is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill and any amendments or motions should not exceed 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. The appeal time for a bill under this section is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. The minority leader can control time in opposition. Additional time can be allotted by leaders during consideration of motions or appeals. Amendments to a bill under this section are generally prohibited, with limited exceptions. No amendments allowed to bills considered under this section in the House or Senate. Division of question not allowed. Motion to suspend rules not permitted. Senate can consider substitute amendments from Committee on Appropriations. Rescissions only allowed in such amendments. The amendment must contain rescissions to the same appropriation Act as the bill being amended and the total amount of budget authority rescinded must be equal to or greater than the original bill. In the Senate, a bill or amendment in the nature of a substitute from the Committee on Appropriations must be rejected before considering a bill that makes rescissions to carry out the President's special message. The President's special message requires any rescinded budget authority to be made available for obligation after certain conditions are met in Congress. Definitions for this process are provided in the section. The section defines terms related to appropriation Acts and legislative days. It also amends rulemaking powers and makes conforming amendments to certain sections of the Act. Section 1015 of the Act (2 U.S.C. 685) is amended to include references to section 1014. This involves changes in subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2), as well as redesignations in subsection (e)(2). Section 1015 of the Act (2 U.S.C. 685) is amended to include references to section 1014, with changes in subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2), as well as redesignations in subsection (e)(2). Additionally, section 1016 of the Act is amended to include references to sections 1012, 1013, or 1014. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act. Title X of the Act is amended by redesignating sections 1013 through 1017 as sections 1014 through 1018 and inserting a new item after section 1012. Section 1013 discusses expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. Section 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 applies to budget authority enacted during the One Hundred Tenth Congress. The President may propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of the One Hundred Eleventh Congress beginning for amounts not considered by the previous Congress. The President can propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of a new Congress starting. A draft bill must accompany the special message, and if not introduced promptly, any Member of the House can do so. The House and Senate will then consider the bill as outlined in section 1013.
